text:
Pricing question:
• Client wants 2-3 blogs per month, 1,000-2,000 words each
• Technical topics in the telco industry
• Each comes with a detailed brief
• Each requires a mix of independent research and interview with a subject matter expert from the company
• Sometimes I’ll have the interview done and recorded, sometimes I have to nudge the person and interview them myself
How much time should I estimate for a post like this? This is a freelance client btw, I have a full-time role already. How much would you charge for this? Ballpark? I don’t want to go too high but I’m afraid I’ll do just that since the interview part scares me a bit. Thanks for your help!

How much time should I estimate for a post like this? This is a freelance client btw, I have a full-time role already. How much would you charge for this? Ballpark? I don’t want to go too high but I’m afraid I’ll do just that since the interview part scares me a bit. Thanks for your help!

text: I wouldn't charge by the hour here. Instead, I'd price it either per 100 words or a flat fee per article. For a technical topic like this with interviews, I'd charge at least $50/100 words, but there are definitely some freelancers who are able to charge much more.

text: never charge by the hour. You end up earning less the faster you work. So you're basically punishing yourself for doing a better job

text: In the last three years I've been paid anywhere between US 50 cents a word and $3 a word for an article under 2,000 words. Newspapers pay the worst (but pay invoices quickly). Large businesses pay the best (but it's hit or miss how quickly they will pay your invoice). Again, this is just my experience. And 2020 has been all over the map.

text:
Three thoughts here:

*1.* (As you're probably already experiencing Elizabeth) There is an entire galaxy of branding info/points of view/template/noise/etc out there to sift through.

Frustrating, especially when trying to learn and hopefully implement on behalf of a client. Would pick a couple "tent pole" resources, perhaps like the one <@U014ZN613LM> recommended above (which I just ordered myself). _*<https://www.amazon.com/Brand-Against-Machine-Marketing-Competition-ebook/dp/B005ZRXBZ4/ref=tmm_kin_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr=|Brand Against the Machine>*_ is another I can recommend personally.

And even though Sinek gets a lot of flak, I think <@U012UL77GUT> is 100% correct in invoking the Golden Circle here. The "brand" should have a Why, How, and What.

And as you work through your tent pole resources, then on to others on the Internet (blogs/podcasts/etc), you can start to "bucket" all the different facets folks employ in branding into the Golden Circle:

Why = Brand purpose, stories...
How = Pillars, mission statements...
What = Reasons to believe, brand Benefits...

This allows you to build a brand "house" from a solid foundation, up.

There is no one way to do this. But it helps to set yourself a bar to clear, that being: _"Are we capturing something here that codifies this particular business in a way that is directionally/strategically useful?"_

That last bit's particularly important in my opinion because if you've crafted a brand that doesn't help guide the business and its marketing/content you've got little more than a piece of paper or .ppt that someone paid a lot of money for. Which seems to happen a lot. That's why...

*2.* _*<https://www.amazon.com/Knowing-Doing-Gap-Companies-Knowledge-Action/dp/1578511240|The Knowing/Doing Gap>*_ is an invaluable read. Folks have brands they don't use. Others pay for brands they don't go on to use or HAVE brands that we (as marketers/creators) have NO IDEA how to use. Can't always fix situations like this. But helpful to understand why they happen. That books a good life-read, in general.

*3.* Tin Man from the Wizard of Oz is certainly an amazing machine. But without his heart, he'd just be an immaculately organized hunk of cold metal.

Think of a brand you're helping to build/capture as an engine (again, big point of a brand is to drive action). How do you ensure you've got some amazing fuel at the heart of this engine.

For this, I've never found anything better/more useful than _*<https://www.amazon.com/Archetypes-Branding-Toolkit-Creatives-Strategists/dp/1440308187/ref=asc_df_1440308187/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=312021428070&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=7294453828347883483&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9019670&hvtargid=pla-564430866610&psc=1&tag=&ref=&adgrpid=60223809017&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvadid=312021428070&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=7294453828347883483&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9019670&hvtargid=pla-564430866610|Archetypes in Branding: A Toolkit for Creatives and Strategists>*_. Long story short, it's a way to build the brand on the business as a Character.

But not just any Character. Through this book, you're leveraging archetypes that cultures worldwide have woven stories around for centuries. That's a bit heady for a Wed morning, yes. But the *<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2F7Wwew8X4Y|Monomyth, Joseph Campell stuff>* makes for great fuel for branding engines.

I also love the discovery process they recommend going through in the book itself. With a bit of practice, it makes the all-important WHY tangible and emotionally engaging for a client.

Captured some of how that process looks in an old work thing *<https://www.thiscouldbegood.com/client-seven-leaf-canada-s-first-in|here>* if you're curious.

This is a lot, but so is branding. :slightly_smiling_face: Hoping some of this will be helpful to you.

Best wishes.

text: Feedback from a non-writer, but someone who used to freelance outside a 9-5 as well... Consider this: What dollar amount will make it *worth your time*, particularly outside of your 9-5? A figure below that, and you may end up just resenting the project and struggling to 'make time' for it.

worth your time
, particularly outside of your 9-5? A figure below that, and you may end up just resenting the project and struggling to 'make time' for it.

text:
I'm looking to hire a part-time contractor to help with content marketing (writing/editing blog posts) and social media (primarily LinkedIn and Twitter).

Can this be the same person? SHOULD this be the same person so that there is consistency for the brand? Or are the two skills separate enough to recommend two people work on this?

For more context, the customer audience is for early-stage tech founders. My product/service helps them take their product to market so the voice and context will be important (compared to a consumer brand).

elements.text:

For more context, the customer audience is for early-stage tech founders. My product/service helps them take their product to market so the voice and context will be important (compared to a consumer brand).

text: I think people who freelance full-time might have a better chance of having both these skill sets in their arsenal than someone who specializes in-house somewhere. So I don’t think it’s impossible!

elements.text: I think people who freelance full-time might have a better chance of having both these skill sets in their arsenal than someone who specializes in-house somewhere. So I don’t think it’s impossible!

text: Absolutely. I do both daily, for example, and I find that it's easier when the person managing your socials also has a hand in creating the content as they usually know best how to cross-promote your content.

text:
Hi, all! A client of ours has a blog that features bylines by various thought leaders in the company. But occasionally the thought leaders leave. The client asked what best practices are for those bylines (which are often ghost written). Give them the brand’s byline (some posts have that already)? Leave it as is? Replace it with a current employee’s byline?

Grateful for any insight you have!

elements.text:
Hi, all! A client of ours has a blog that features bylines by various thought leaders in the company. But occasionally the thought leaders leave. The client asked what best practices are for those bylines (which are often ghost written). Give them the brand’s byline (some posts have that already)? Leave it as is? Replace it with a current employee’s byline?

Grateful for any insight you have!

text: <http://monday.com|monday.com> features a few articles that are simply bylined: "(From) All of us at <http://monday.com|monday.com>"

elements.text: monday.com
features a few articles that are simply bylined: "(From) All of us at
monday.com

text:
We've dealt with this (on a small scale). The most important consideration for us was follow up- if someone read the piece and wanted to quote us/use our research data/ask a question about what we wrote would they reach someone who could help? In our case we were able to leave the bylines as-is because the person who left's emails were auto-forwarded to the new person in his role so we could coordinate partnering with those who reached out.

Of course there are likely other considerations around brand-building, but from a logistics standpoint this was our approach!

text:
If the post isn't getting a lot of traffic, I'd consider taking it down and/or updating it with a new byline and new information.

If it is getting a lot of traffic, then generalize the byline as mentioned

text: I own a business that sells technical blog posts as a productized service offering, and based on my best understanding of how what you're describing maps to how we price content, I'd charge $1,250 on average (factoring in the upper and lower end of that word count spectrum)

elements.text: I own a business that sells technical blog posts as a productized service offering, and based on my best understanding of how what you're describing maps to how we price content, I'd charge $1,250 on average (factoring in the upper and lower end of that word count spectrum)

text: So, absent any other context, standard freelancer play would be to undercut agency pricing, but not so much as not to be worth doing

text: I'd say the upper limit of my budget is $2k per month. Not looking to do paid ads or sponsored posts for now

text: A friend of mine is hiring for a SEO content mktg manager and needs some inspo for interview questions! What are you go-to questions for understanding someone's SEO knowledge (doesn't have to be super technical) and website management capabilities?

elements.text: A friend of mine is hiring for a SEO content mktg manager and needs some inspo for interview questions! What are you go-to questions for understanding someone's SEO knowledge (doesn't have to be super technical) and website management capabilities?

text: I would ask how they stay up to date on the latest SEO changes! and also give them a take-home test to write title tags/meta descriptions

elements.text: I would ask how they stay up to date on the latest SEO changes! and also give them a take-home test to write title tags/meta descriptions

text: I was always a fan of posing a real potential project/challenge they'd be tasked with, and ask them how they'd approach solving it... whether that's ranking for a specific keyword, or crafting a creative project, or building community (whatever's most central to the role), but with a real life example. And if the answer is too brief, prompting them to "tell me more".

text:
What are your recommendations for professional development courses/consultants for content strategists?

My company has some budget set aside for managers and directors to do some continuing education. We have a Lynda account, but not sure where to start there.

For me, looking to sharpen skills around these areas:
• Scaling content processes (writing, editing, tracking)
• Keyword mapping
• How to track performance of content (beyond just looking up URLs in GSC or GA), say, in Google Data Studio
Taking all suggestions — I know there are some threads here about this, feel free to @ me in those.

elements.text:

Scaling content processes (writing, editing, tracking)
Keyword mapping
How to track performance of content (beyond just looking up URLs in GSC or GA), say, in Google Data Studio
Taking all suggestions — I know there are some threads here about this, feel free to @ me in those.

text:
<@U011QQDDSJV>

Superpath Pro feels like it's the resource looking to grow into servicing content folks particularly, but if you're in CMCG, I assume you're aware of it? (<https://pro.superpath.co/membership>) ~ and if so, I'd be curious to know why it does or doesn't fit your need.

I ask because I'm actually in the process of trying to build an eLearning business around a similar question, outside the specific realm of content strategists (more focus on: people who have been forced into remote work and need soft skills development).

Oop, I see your edit—looks like you're after 'hard skills' vs 'human skills' ~ though I'd continue to be curious if there's demand in your org for the 'how to remote work better' side of proDev

text:
Hi everyone! I’m a senior content marketing manager moving more in the direction of demand gen trying to better align inbound and sales - and looking to possibly add a business development rep to the team to help assist and optimize inbound conversion rates.

I have a good idea of the pain points we have around attracting and moving top and middle of funnel leads to conversion, but I’m not sure what this role would look like. Any advice on attributes, skillsets or core functionalities would be much appreciated!

To clarify, this person’s goals involve KPIs around qualifying inbound, content-driven leads to more successfully move top of funnel leads to the bottom of the funnel.

elements.text:

To clarify, this person’s goals involve KPIs around qualifying inbound, content-driven leads to more successfully move top of funnel leads to the bottom of the funnel.

text:
one of the most efficient ways is definitely having a shared drive or a Dropbox folder.  We do that at <http://Automate.io|Automate.io>
However, the problem arises when your library grows and you actually have to search for files and folders in the drive. So, recently we are trying a new option. We already have our Slack and G-Drive connected. We have set up a bot on Slack wherein if anyone wants any information, like say, editorial guidelines, they just need to type in those words and the bot will search and show items from the drive that goes by the title -'editorial guidelines' or has these terms.

Another idea we are yet to explore practically is - to launch a knowledge base site for the internal team... much like the FAQs we have on websites. For now, the Slack-Gdrive integration is working well. :slightly_smiling_face:

Another idea we are yet to explore practically is - to launch a knowledge base site for the internal team... much like the FAQs we have on websites. For now, the Slack-Gdrive integration is working well.

text:
If it's an SEO and content marketing manager, I'd expect the person you hire to be someone who is focused on content and understands SEO (vs. the other way around.)

In that case, for SEO, I think all they need to be able to convey understanding of is how to use organic search effectively as a distribution channel, which means understanding how they would approach building a topic (keyword) strategy – maybe even walking you through a very brief version – being able to describe how Google ranks things, and maybe some best practices for making that channel effective.

elements.text:
If it's an SEO and content marketing manager, I'd expect the person you hire to be someone who is focused on content and understands SEO (vs. the other way around.)

In that case, for SEO, I think all they need to be able to convey understanding of is how to use organic search effectively as a distribution channel, which means understanding how they would approach building a topic (keyword) strategy – maybe even walking you through a very brief version – being able to describe how Google ranks things, and maybe some best practices for making that channel effective.

text:
I would consider starting with a Slack channel,  something like "#awesome-insights", and see what kind of adoption you get. maybe give out some kind of kudos via Slack so people are motivated to share there.

Another option is to do a TIL (either verbally or in a doc or Slack) for your weekly team sync.

If you can get some traction there, a simple Notion page or even a Google Doc is really easy to search – but then again, so is Slack!
